Award.AwardTitle: REU Site in Micro/Nano-Structured Materials, Therapeutics, and Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This three year REU Site program at Auburn University is interdisciplinary in nature and has a strong focus on micro and nano-material science and technology. Specific topics will include materials synthesis and characterization, micro/nano particle formation processes, nanomechanics of thin films, carbon-nanotubes, inorganic nano-rods, MEMS, nanoparticulate systems and micro films for drug delivery, nanofibers yarns and fabrics, nanoparticle thin films, and others. The program involves fourteen faculty mentors from diverse academic departments, including Chemical Engineering, Chemistry, Mechanical and Materials Engineering, Polymer and Fiber Engineering, Pharmacy, and Biosystems Engineering.

REU participants will be paired with research faculty mentors to work in their laboratories on projects focused on micro/nano-structured materials, therapeutics, and devices. Students will be introduced to skills such as literature searching and review, research design, laboratory research techniques, written and oral presentation, as well as working in a team environment. Students will participate as a group in weekly seminars and workshops that allow cross cultivation of the individual research experience as well as address professional development (e.g., research methods, transferring to a bachelor degree program, steps in the graduate school application process, technical writing, effective presentation skills, professional etiquette training, ethics in science and engineering, patents and commercialization, etc.)

The broader impacts of the proposed project include: 1)providing an interdisciplinary research environment to a diverse group of undergraduate participants from Alabama and Gulf State four-year institutions and community colleges with limited opportunity to engage in research activities; 2)increasing the number of women and underrepresented minorities in research;3)encouraging community college students and siblings to pursue bachelor degrees in science and technology areas;4)encouraging students and siblings at undergraduate institutions to pursue graduate studies;5)enhancing professional development and career guidance;6)fostering undergraduate research opportunities throughout Auburn University; and 7)promoting faculty development through the undergraduate research mentoring experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU site at Auburn University targeted a diverse group of undergraduate participants from four-year institutions and community/junior colleges that had limited opportunity to engage in research activities and/or were underrepresented in science and engineering. We count  63 mentored undergraduate alumni from across the country. The program involved fourteen faculty mentors from six different science and engineering disciplines within an interdisciplinary focus spanning four different colleges (College of Engineering, College of Sciences and Mathematics, School of Pharmacy, College of Agriculture). Providing undergraduate students with research experience directly led to an increase in student perseverance in higher education, higher graduation rates, and a greater number of students pursuing bachelor and graduate degrees.The Auburn University program trained, encouraged, and motivated the next generation of scientists and engineers toward advanced degrees and technical challenges. Close to 80% of the REU students from this program have entered graduate or professional school with many receiving national and regional awards. Their work also led to publishable research.The REU Site was interdisciplinary in nature and advanced knowledge across a broad range of scientific and engineering disciplines.

REU participants were paired with faculty mentors to work in their laboratories on research projects focused on micro/nano-structured materials, therapeutics, and devices.  Students were introduced to skills such as literature searching and review, research design, laboratory research techniques, written and oral presentation, as well as working in a team environment. Students also participated as a group in weekly seminars and workshops that allowed cross cultivation of the individual research experience as well as professional development (e.g., research methods, transferring to a BS degree program, graduate school and the graduate school application process, technical writing, effective presentation skills, professional etiquette training, ethics in science and engineering, patents and commercialization). Social events occurred during the program and participating students lived together close to campus. This program created individuals who not only conducted better science but had a better understanding of science and engineering and its impact  in the world. This program trained  future technology leaders and created a more technically advanced and diverse workforce to increase our country’s global competiveness.The REU participants shared these experiences with their friends and family making better informed citizens outside the boundaries of science, engineering, and the academic world.
